awd_titl_txt: Engaged Learning through Creativity in Mathematics and Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of Creativity in Mathematics and Science (CMS) is to develop and test an innovative model of instruction that highlights the role of creative thought in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM), and that engages students in thoughtful and creative approaches to scientific and mathematical practices. This project will (i) develop course modules on creative thinking for science and non-science majors, (ii) provide a two-year engaged student experience for CMS Scholars, (iii) conduct research on student achievement and changes to students' perceptions about STEM learning, and (iv) transfer the successful elements to local high schools and a community college. All elements of the CMS project are collaborative and interdisciplinary. For example, students will work in teams with mentors from multiple disciplines, and faculty members will collaborate with leaders from high schools, community colleges, and industry to develop, deliver, and transfer effective instructional practices. The project will to add to the literature on the role of creative instruction in effective undergraduate STEM education.  

CMS will encourage the rethinking of undergraduate STEM education by deliberately exposing students to the creative explorations that drive the STEM fields. The project will address the documented need to provide students with authentic learning experiences and to have them engage in activities that model the work of STEM professionals. Students will experience the natural creativity in STEM and become more science-literate citizens. The development, implementation, assessment, and refinement cycle will allow for the identification of the successful elements of the project, thus informing its adoption in other STEM disciplines and academic settings. The project and its outcomes will contribute to the research on teaching and learning in STEM by introducing new learning materials and teaching techniques, disseminating results of learning under this innovation, and generating evidence regarding the role of creativity as a motivator in undergraduate STEM education.

por.por_cntn:
The Engaged Learning through Creativity in Mathematics and Science (CMS) project at Montclair State University (MSU) involved MSU and community college faculty and students as they reconsidered the role of creativity in STEM. Motivated by past projects that challenged students to see the importance of creativity in STEM, the CMS project endeavored to redesign undergraduate curricula, involve students in creative projects around science and mathematics, collaborate with colleagues from other disciplines, and engage the general community.

A major outcome of the CMS project was the redesign of a general education mathematics course originally called “Contemporary Mathematics” and officially renamed “Creative Thinking through Mathematics” as a result of this project. This course typically enrolls about 500 students each semester. Early in the project, the project leaders co-taught the course, and designed and revised instructional modules based on their implementation. These modules led to the core curriculum of the redesigned course. Regular workshops given by the PIs involved MSU faculty, Bergen Community College faculty, K12 teachers, and graduate students. The objective of these workshops was to bring educators together to discuss how creativity can be emphasized in STEM education. 

The CMS project extended beyond the classroom. As one example, the project leaders collaborated with Gandini Juggling, a world-renowned professional juggling troupe, and MSU’s Arts + Cultural Programming at Kasser Theater, that involved the creation of a juggling unit for undergraduate mathematics, student exhibits that were showcased before the Gandini Juggling performance, and workshops on the connections between art and mathematics given to the general public. Another example of a deliberate attempt to connect mathematics and the arts through creativity was a fieldtrip taken by 31 MSU students to the SHED exhibit hall in New York City to view the Agnes Denes exhibit. 

Research related to the CMS project has led to four publications (with an additional three currently under review) in STEM education journals, a dissertation by the project doctoral student on a professional development program for teaching mathematics through creativity in middle grades, four presentations at national and international conferences, and numerous talks given to audiences ranging from community residents to academics. Publications include a study on the implementation of alternative assessments in mathematics class, a book chapter on the role of creativity in online teaching (under review), and a report on the implementation of a module on the mathematics of juggling. 

The CMS project provided an opportunity to deliberately and carefully connect STEM disciplines with other disciplines through creativity. The intellectual merits of the project stem from the outcomes related to these efforts. Through its associated publications and presentations, as well as outreach to community college and K12 partners, the project contributed to the research and discussions on the role of creativity in STEM and led to permanent curricular changes at MSU. The broader impacts of the CMS project were realized through its outreach efforts, both to academics and the general public. The project sought to challenge common conceptions of mathematics held by students, faculty, and the general public as a way to make the learning of mathematics more relevant and accessible to all.
